noun.description: A large rectangular piece of cotton or other fabric, used on a bed to cover the mattress and as a layer beneath blankets when these are used.
A rectangular piece of paper, especially one of a standard size produced commercially and used for writing and printing on.
A broad flat piece of material such as metal or glass.
examples: the small pipe has been formed from a flat sheet of bronze

noun.description: An extensive unbroken surface area of something.

verb.description: Cover with or wrap in a sheet or sheets.

origin: Old English scēata lower corner of a sail, of Germanic origin; related to Old Norse skauti kerchief (see also sheet).
phrases: he reclined, two sheets to the wind, his back propped against the wall
I hadn't seen much of him at the party, but as we talked I realized that he was maybe not three, but at least two sheets to the wind.
We were three sheets to the wind on The Cutty.
No, I mean, that kiss, way back when you were three sheets to the wind, when you kissed me, that was your first kiss, ever?
Once the Times identifies some emerging trend, that trend is already three sheets to the wind.
